articles.headline: Demands Grow for Facebook to Explain Its Privacy Policies
articles.snippet: The Federal Trade Commission confirmed an inquiry as a group of attorneys general asked Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, for more information.
articles.abstract: The Federal Trade Commission confirmed an inquiry as a group of attorneys general asked Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, for more information.
articles.lead_paragraph: A parade of regulators, politicians and law enforcement officials demanded to know more about Facebook’s privacy practices on Monday, as the fallout from the company’s relationship with a political data firm continued to spread.
articles.byline: By Tiffany Hsu and Cecilia Kang

articles.headline: Trump’s New Judicial Litmus Test: Shrinking ‘the Administrative State’
articles.snippet: The Trump administration has been surprisingly frank in saying it wants to use the courts to curb the power of federal agencies, a longstanding goal of conservatives.
articles.abstract: The Trump administration has been surprisingly frank in saying it wants to use the courts to curb the power of federal agencies, a longstanding goal of conservatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It has been practically a given that anyone nominated for a federal judgeship by a Republican president had to pass an unspoken litmus test — usually on abortion but often on any number of divisive social issues.

articles.headline: How an Outraged Europe Agreed to a Hard Line on Putin
articles.snippet: Faced with new aggressiveness from the newly re-elected Putin, the E.U. backed Britain on the Skripal poisoning and sent a strong message to Moscow.
articles.abstract: Faced with new aggressiveness from the newly re-elected Putin, the E.U. backed Britain on the Skripal poisoning and sent a strong message to Moscow.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — When leaders of the European Union gathered last Thursday night for a working dinner inside their lavish new headquarters, the conversation turned to Russia. Over scallops and lamb, Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain shared intelligence detailing the high probability that the Russian state had carried out the poisoning of a former Russian spy on British soil.

articles.headline: The Post-World War II Order Is Under Assault From the Powers That Built It
articles.snippet: Since the end of World War II, the victorious powers have promoted trade, democracy and collective security. Now, that order is under assault.
articles.abstract: Since the end of World War II, the victorious powers have promoted trade, democracy and collective security. Now, that order is under assault.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — History was not supposed to turn out this way.

articles.headline: New York Fed Weighs a Wall Street Overseer, and Left Spies an Opening
articles.snippet: Progressive groups want a New York Fed chief who is independent of the financial sector, a voice for labor and a reflection of diversity.
articles.abstract: Progressive groups want a New York Fed chief who is independent of the financial sector, a voice for labor and a reflection of diversity.
articles.lead_paragraph: When William C. Dudley, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, announced that he planned to step down, progressives and pro-labor groups saw a rare opportunity to influence an important economic policy appointment over which President Trump has no say.

articles.headline: After Stormy Daniels, Republicans Face a Referendum on Trump’s Conduct
articles.snippet: As gun control, immigration and taxes energize voters in both parties, allegations of an affair have intensified discomfort with the president’s behavior.
articles.abstract: As gun control, immigration and taxes energize voters in both parties, allegations of an affair have intensified discomfort with the president’s behavior.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Representative Ryan Costello of Pennsylvania announced on Sunday that he would join more than 40 other congressional Republicans not seeking re-election in November, he left no doubt about the reason: President Trump’s conduct made it impossible to talk about anything else.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Citigroup Acted. Now, Two New Ideas on How Banks Can Limit Gun Sales.
articles.snippet: Merchant codes could be adapted to distinguish retailers that sell guns under a “best practices” policy. And GPS could be used to pinpoint gun shows and restrict transactions at those locations.
articles.abstract: Merchant codes could be adapted to distinguish retailers that sell guns under a “best practices” policy. And GPS could be used to pinpoint gun shows and restrict transactions at those locations.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Saturday afternoon, as hundreds of thousands of people joined the March for Our Lives around the nation, I was on the phone with Michael Corbat, chief executive of Citigroup.

articles.headline: Scores of Russians Expelled by U.S. and Its Allies Over U.K. Poisoning
articles.snippet: The mass expulsion of Russian personnel in the United States was the largest ever, yet the president avoided any public condemnation of Russia’s role in an attack in Britain.
articles.abstract: The mass expulsion of Russian personnel in the United States was the largest ever, yet the president avoided any public condemnation of Russia’s role in an attack in Britain.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump ordered the expulsion of 60 Russian officials on Monday, joining a coordinated campaign by two dozen countries to retaliate for the poisoning of a former Russian spy in Britain in a Cold War-style escalation that again highlighted the disparity between the president’s words and actions.
articles.byline: By Katie Rogers and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Behind the Rise of China’s HNA: The Chairman’s Brother
articles.snippet: Wang Wei, the younger brother of HNA’s co-chairman, has been a critical surrogate in the rise of the Chinese company as a global deal maker.
articles.abstract: Wang Wei, the younger brother of HNA’s co-chairman, has been a critical surrogate in the rise of the Chinese company as a global deal maker.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a former Microsoft executive decided to sell his collection of eight golf properties in Washington State, a small Chinese company started quietly negotiating for them.
articles.byline: By David Barboza and Michael Forsythe

articles.headline: Waymo, a Google Spinoff, Ramps Up Its Driverless-Car Effort
articles.snippet: The company says it will buy up to 20,000 electric cars from Jaguar Land Rover as it strives to put a ride service into operation within two years.
articles.abstract: The company says it will buy up to 20,000 electric cars from Jaguar Land Rover as it strives to put a ride service into operation within two years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Waymo, the driverless-car company that was spun out of Google, has pushed farther ahead in self-driving cars than any of the automakers or other technology companies trying to pioneer the field.

articles.headline: Putin’s Grim Reality: Public Fury Over Children’s Deaths in Mall
articles.snippet: The Russian president visited Siberia to demand an inquiry into a fire there that killed at least 64 people. Thousands protested nearby.
articles.abstract: The Russian president visited Siberia to demand an inquiry into a fire there that killed at least 64 people. Thousands protested nearby.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — At the end of a month that has seen him unveil new “invincible” missiles, announce a space mission to Mars and secure a sky-high vote in Russia’s election, President Vladimir V. Putin faced a grim reality on the ground Tuesday: a nation enraged by the deaths of children trapped in a burning mall in Siberia.

articles.headline: Trump’s China Policy Has a Flaw: It Makes China the Winner
articles.snippet: Confronting Beijing over trade abuses is not without merit. But rejecting economic alliances opens the way to Chinese initiatives around the region.
articles.abstract: Confronting Beijing over trade abuses is not without merit. But rejecting economic alliances opens the way to Chinese initiatives around the region.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since the days of the Nixon administration nearly 50 years ago, American policy has aimed to steer China out of its isolation to prosper in the global market economy. There needn’t be conflict between the established superpower and the emerging giant, the best strategic minds argued. As it grew rich, they reasoned, China could be integrated peacefully into the institutional framework built by the Western powers from the rubble of World War II.
